answers.answer: Dogs do not tolerate steroids nearly as well as cats do, and they come with quite a list of possible side effects.  One that show up fairly frequently in dogs is diabetes.  Normally a short course of steroids will not cause any problems, but every dog's system is different and they all react differently to meds.  Just like with people, what doesn't seem to affect one dog in the least can throw another dog into a complete tailspin.A large increase in water intake, especially when coupled with weight loss, is one of the main red flags for diabetes.  A simple blood test can tell your vet whether or not your dog is diabetic, and it can then go on to lead a normal life with medication and/or a carefully controlled diet.  Of course, there is always also a chance that it isn't diabetes and it is merely something that just happened.I would give the vet a call back and tell them that you would like to bring him in to have them give him the once-over to make sure he is OK because of the symptoms he is now having.  Please post back and let us know how he makes out and what the vet says.Ghilly
